text: Thank you- I'll take a look into that

How are you recognised at work? What training does your company offer? What would you say your strengths and weaknesses are? How do you use your strengths and talents at work? What are your colleagues like?
What do you mean by recognised?

In terms of training, a lot of the people I work with are given training in accountancy, as we work in a lot of financial disputes. In general, I went on lots of courses at the beginning of my career, but most of what I have learned has been on the job - that means I've made mistakes a long the way, but hopefully won't make them again!

Strengths and weaknesses - good question, been a while since I've had an interview to answer that one! Strengths - I am confident, and will argue with anyone. That's gotten me a lot of respect from senior people. Obviously I have to be respectful, but most people in my industry realise that argument is the best way to get to a good case to present in court, so it gets me a long way. The same would be true in the legal world. Using that at work - I just argue a lot. Most recently in my meeting on Monday, presenting to the CEO and the rest of the board of my client in Algeria, I was arguing why they should accept as true something that they are famous of not believing (that was actually mentioned in one of the presentations at the conference today).

Weakness - always the hardest question to answer. Probably the thing I find most challenging is dealing with people who either don't like arguing or who just don't understand the argument. While most of the people I deal with are very intelligent, some have been promoted too far, so it can be a real challenge having to balance the need to be correct and the need to not annoy a client too much. I had a lot of difficulty early in my career hiding it if I thought my client wasn't as smart as they should be, which I think I have managed to deal with now.

My colleagues are generally pretty amazing. I am lucky to work in an office of very intelligent people. The team I manage is very close - we go for drinks or dinner regularly, and get on very well outside of work. I think that's an important part of being an effective team, as long as professional boundaries exist in the office.
Those answered, I will reverse a couple of the questions on you - what are your strengths and weaknesses? How do you think they will help in the legal industry?
